snippet: Only 25 percent of American teenagers were employed last summer, but the long-term payoffs from a summer job are hard to beat, according to a new study.
abstract: Alina Tugend Shortcuts column; Brookings Institution's Metropolitan Policy Program study finds that summer jobs for teenagers are tougher than ever to come by, but long-term payoffs are worth effort put into finding one; number of teenagers employed nationwide is at near-historic low, with about 25 percent of nation's 16-19-year-olds in work force in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Only 25 percent of American teenagers were employed last summer, but the long-term payoffs from a summer job are hard to beat, according to a new study.

headline.main: If a Teenager Lands a Summer Job, the Value Is Lasting
headline.print_headline: If a Teenager Lands a Summer Job, the Value Is Lasting
